section.para: This document provides an in-depth description of Â Release for users at a client site. consists of a set of modules (or functions) giving your company online access to various services offered by your bank. Each module provides options to initiate transactions and follow up with them. There are additional functions that provide enquiry, reporting and calendar management facilities.

section.title: Audience
section.para: This manual is addressed to a user at a client's place, and describes the end-user functions in the client user interface.

section.title: Types of User
section.para: A system is used by two types of organisation: banks, and companies that are customers of banks. The latter are referred to as "customers" or "clients", with these terms being used interchangeably.
The term "bank group" is used to refer to a site with overriding authority over the system, such as a bank's head office.
A member of the staff of a client or bank is called a "user". A user with administrator privileges and permissions is called an "administrator".
A system has two different user interfaces: for a user at a client, and for a user at a bank or bank group.

Both interfaces include a menu of Services or System Features, containing functions for administering and configuring the system. The rest of the interface contains end-user functions. The functions available to a given user depends on that user's privileges.

section.title: Overview
section.para: This section introduces the basic concepts and terminology used throughout .

section.title: Products and Transactions
section.para: The financial products that a bank can provide, such as letters of credit, standby letters of credit, shipping guarantees, loans, and so on, are referred to as "products".

The communications between bank and client about an individual instance of a product typically consist of a sequences of messages. For example, the communications regarding a letter of credit would typically consist of:

listitem.para: Possibly a request from the client to amend the request
The bank's formal response to the amendment request
Possibly a free-format message from the client to the bank containing further discussion
The bank's response to the free-format message
Possibly further free-format messages between the client and the bank

section.para: These individual messages are called "transactions" or "transaction events". Those sent by the bank in reply to a client message are called "reporting messages" (because the bank is "reporting back" - they should not be confused with reports produced using the Report Designer module). The whole set of messages concerning one instance of a individual product is called a "file" (this represents a "file of documents" and should not be confused with the files that can be uploaded containing details of a transaction).
The initial request from the client is often called the "initiation" of the file.

section.title: System ID
section.para: When a new file is created - for example, a client user creates a new Letter of Credit request - gives it a unique reference number called its System ID. This is used throughout the system to identify it.
The System ID consists of a 2 character Product code describing the type of transaction, followed by the year and month and a unique number allocated to this transaction file.

section.title: Permissions
section.para: Which modules you, as an individual user, have access to, and what you can do in each module, depends on permissions granted you by your company's administrator. These permissions in turn have been granted to your company by the bank.
Your permissions are often referred to as privileges, authority or authorisation. These four terms are used interchangeably.
These should not be confused with authentication, which means your login ID and password.

section.title: Workflow
section.para: Many functions in follow much the same pattern. As a client user, you send a request to the bank on behalf of your company. As an example, this might be a request for a Letter of Credit or a request for a drawdown on a loan. The bank replies with a message acknowledging the request, and approving or rejecting it.
Further messages can be sent to the bank, discussing or amending the request.

When the bank's reply (reporting message) arrives, it is shown in the Recent Notifications list in the Trade Events portlet on the home pages of the company's users. It has a tick if the bank has approved the transaction, and a cross if the bank has declined the transaction.
There are also functions that display lists of these transactions, so their progress can be monitored.

When creating a transaction, it can be saved at any time , without sending it, and can be continued by the original or another user at a later stage. Its status will be marked as 'Draft' or 'Incomplete', depending on the type of transaction, and the list being viewed.

When a transaction is submitted (sent to the bank, it may be that the user submitting the transaction has insufficient authority to do so - usually because of a transactional value limit. It is then automatically saved but not sent and given a status of 'Unsigned' or 'Uncontrolled' depending on the type of transaction, and the list being viewed. It must then be submitted by another user with the appropriate authorities required to send it.
